body: @bwmcadams, is this PR still valid?
@csantanapr, can you close this if you can verify the above works.
Seems somewhat related to https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/issues/3014.
@dubeejw the intent is still there; I have to check the upstream changes though. Will update.
Closing as fixed.
@csantanapr, is this still valid?
@mdeuser, any more comments?
@csantanapr, can this be closed?
@dubeejw yes still valid, but will need to be updated to resolve conflicts; I'll get back to it asap.
This is I think a duplicate of https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/issues/3120

agreed looks like a duplicate, however at least one of our environments we are getting monitoring failures of "connection reset" when this occurs, but that may be unrelated; And this behavior was unexpected (didn't realize that code changes would be required to cause a re-init). Will verify that this does not occur when there are code changes, and close based on that. (and will separately look at the other issue which may be more related to using paused containers)
Pushed changes to use ansible/files/runtimes.json since the runtimes were removed from ansible/group_varz/all.

Here's a proposed patch https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/pull/3155 to get counts with an explicit API call:
`GET /namespaces/_/activations?count=true` return `{"activations": N}`

i think this is a good idea. all of the Read APIs should use streaming, never touching the controller's  scala heap. plus, the list api can easily be implemented client-side, possibly with a more attractive user experience: the UI can begin rendering as soon as any one of the four sub-requests completes.
#3152 will update the docs to drop this step from the instructions (See https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/pull/3152/commits/859559b5461f07f302183d1224ed7549071d53f4).
@mhenke1 Can you please review?
Is there anyone who can review this please?
@dgrove-oss thanks, I have updated the PR according to the review.
@csantanapr should we make this its own repo as with the other runtimes?
better yet if you have a hand full of triggers, you don't need to fetch all your 1000 actions to get the trigger list.
@tysonnorris any possibility that the action itself has a bug? This happens if the action proxy crashes due to a memory leak for example.

+1 is there a resource leak that causes the container to crash?
you can just run the same action 20+ times without deleting it with 100ms think time and see if it also crashes then.

Looks like there is one test failure: 
```

whisk.core.cli.test.WskBasicUsageTests > Wsk actions should create, and invoke an action that utilizes an invalid docker container with appropriate error FAILED
    org.scalatest.exceptions.TestFailedException: "Failed to provision resources to run the action." was not equal to "Failed to pull container image 'boguschgac47qtmfgbscq'."
```

The code is pretty simple: `function main(){return {};}`
I haven't been able to script it to crash; I'll investigate update here (or create a new issue) if I get it to the point of reproducing on demand.

Pushed a commit that will use PureConfig. Will need someone to take a look.

Would this change anything from an end-user perspective when calling `wsk list`? That is, with this REST API change, would there be an associated change to the CLIs so that the command returns the same thing or would the user now have to list actions, triggers, rules, and packages separately?
`wsk list` can preserve the behavior today, this is an implementation detail, not a user facing change otherwise.

I want to know what kinds of tests would be required.
Whether to check volume is correctly mapped between container and host?

If there are any similar test cases for nginx configuration volume mapping, I may refer to that.
I actually have a pull request to remove this from the docs. It’s not needed anymore.
See https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/pull/3152/commits/859559b5461f07f302183d1224ed7549071d53f4. If you’d like to update this pr accordingly I’m happy to merge it.

@rabbah  Opened PR #3162 with initial approach which uses reflection to determine the type property value based on entity class name. This approach has potential issues like

1. Add slight overhead due to use of reflection
2. The type value may change in entity class name is refactored later causing backwarnd compatibility issue

Other possible approaches can be

1. Add type property explicitly with each type
2. OR derive the property in `WhiskDocument` based on same logic as used in CouchDb views

Let me know which approach should be taken

At first glance I think adding type property explicitly is more direct and clean. An abstract method in WhiskEntity that all the subtypes must implement which returns a string and added to the properties written in the WhiskEntity base serializer.
Will be replaced by: #3163

Due to API GW lack of `parameters` support under the path object,  In a discussion with @jessealva yesterday, we agreed to
1. do not add code to restrict where the `parameters` json block can go
2. remove any test that leverages a path level `parameters` swagger file
3. open issue against api gw for path level `parameters` support.  tag the issue with the OpenWhisk tag.  https://github.ibm.com/apimesh/squad-api-fusion/issues
Replaced by #3165
sorry, this feature was already added. my bad

For reference, the `version` of the activation record is the action's semver: https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/blob/master/core/invoker/src/main/scala/whisk/core/containerpool/ContainerProxy.scala#L472
@chetanmeh, can you fix the conflicting build.gradle file?
answering my question: the `waitOnView` is checking the wrong index. The filtering by name using a different view. So need to adjust the wait.

rodric,

I really appreciate even though it is short lived patch.
The following discussion helped deepen my understanding.

https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/issues/693

The build failure is in ActivationsApiTests which I think is not related to changes here per #3027

```
whisk.core.controller.test.ActivationsApiTests > Activations API should get summary activation by namespace and action name FAILED
    org.scalatest.exceptions.TestFailedException: 2 was not equal to 1
        at org.scalatest.MatchersHelper$.indicateFailure(MatchersHelper.scala:340)
        at org.scalatest.Matchers$ShouldMethodHelper$.shouldMatcher(Matchers.scala:6668)
        at org.scalatest.Matchers$AnyShouldWrapper.should(Matchers.scala:6704)
```
Fixed the conflict

The port of the internal kafka bus is configurable at https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/blob/master/ansible/group_vars/all#L69. All of our configuration should be relative to that setting so changing that (+ redeploying) should give you the desired effect.

Since you mention there are multi-arch images, what would be needed to accomplish your goal?

OpenWhisk makes use of external images (like for kafka and couchdb) and ideally we wouldn't build those on our own.

For the images we build ourselves though, it'd be pretty cool to have those be multi-arch ARM ready.
These docs are so central to the initial user experience though. I think having seperate cli docs in the mentioned cli repo is ok but I would not remove the docs we have here.
PG3 1632 successful
Want to give some background why to remove those `println` statements?
@markusthoemmes I want to solve this issue https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/issues/2882

Thanks for the contribution! And the link to the issue.

Much of the info being leaked is from the dburl property - an alternative would drop or redact some of the sensitive info in this value.
fixed - https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/pull/3173

Hi all, I've been working on multi-architecture for some of the other platforms.  I did need to generate my own Kafka image and my own apigateway image for it to work.  See work I've done at https://github.com/jonpspri/s390x-docker-builds and PR #3133 for direction.  Essentially, you'll need to generate arm-specific equivalent images for kafka and apigateway.  I lack access to an ARM server at the moment, so I can't quite get that rolling yet, but it's on the multi-architecture plan list.
@markusthoemmes @rabbah Any idea why build failed? I suppose my changes shouldn't affect any tested functionality.

We have a [tool](https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/blob/master/tools/build/citool) that can help with this:
```bash
> citool monitor 327229861
whisk.core.controller.test.ActivationsApiTests > Activations API should get summary activation by namespace and action name FAILED
```

This is a known heisenbug - I'll kick travis again and look into fixing the bug.

@dubeejw I rebased this to master and also updated it for the CLI change by pushing a second commit.
pg3/1637 🏃 after rebase.

@rabbah (as discussed off-line)
 The thread opened by this PR is that somebody would be able elevate the system log level for calls to OpenWhisk by passing the X-OW-EXTRA-LOGGING header to the controller and impede the performance of the system.
This performance hit would be restricted by the rate limiting mechanisms and the limited number 
of system level logs, but could be notable nevertheless. 

The risk of such an attack would be very low since it would require a change the configuration of 
nginx (which blocks passing the header) which could be easily mitigated by redeployment   of the original configuration.  

In the light of the risk assessment I would like to go forward with the PR as is.
@markusthoemmes  I have rebased the PR to current master. Can this PR be merged now?

Thank you Markus for providing time and response.

Does redeploying means reinstalling openwhisk or just restarting the
Dockers? Which steps should I perform?

Appreciate your help.

Thanks and regards

> https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/blob/
> master/ansible/group_vars/all#L69. All of our configuration should be
> relative to that setting so changing that (+ redeploying) should give you
> the desired effect.

Well, to make it all work in what I'm doing with 'incubator-openwhisk-cli', I had to add this stanza to 'settings.gradle'.  Maybe we should make this available in 'incubator-openwhisk' as a file to `apply`?  I'm on sleep deprivation, so there could be many reasons that NOT a good idea...

```
def owPath = System.getenv("OPENWHISK_HOME") ?: '../incubator-openwhisk'
def owDirectory = new File(owPath)

if (!owDirectory.exists()) {
    throw new GradleScriptException(
        "Environment variable OPENWHISK_HOME must point to a valid OpenWhisk build", null)
}

[   'common:scala',
    'core:controller',
    'core:invoker',
    'actionRuntimes:nodejs6Action',
    'actionRuntimes:actionProxy',
    'actionRuntimes:pythonAction',
    'actionRuntimes:python2Action',
    'actionRuntimes:javaAction',
    'actionRuntimes:swift3.1.1Action',
    'sdk:docker',
    'tests:dat:blackbox:badaction',
    'tests:dat:blackbox:badproxy'
].each() { p ->
    include p
    project(':'+p).projectDir = new File(owDirectory, p.replaceAll(':','/'))
}

include 'tests'
```

@markusthoemmes I tried a new approach which is NOT to merge, but rather replace the TrieMap/AtomicIntegers each time the distributed data is updated (for activationByInvoker and activationByNamespaceId). 

I added a test in LoadBalancerDataTests ("quickly execute many activations") that demonstrates - note that the accuracy of counts fluctuates with DistributedData Changed events e.g.:

- TrieMaps are updated locally, with additional updates send to shared data
- until shared data update is received, TrieMap is accurate for local data, but not for cluster data
- once a shared data update is received, the TrieMap is rebuilt with data that is accurate for the cluster, but may overwrite some local state (which will arrive with the next cluster update)

Therefore test needs to wait (using Eventually) to receive counts for all the activations. 

Some rough testing numbers:
Running same test on previous (async) code takes 4.5s for 100k activations, and on this code takes ~1.2s for 100k activations; Meanwhile LocalLoadBalancerData takes ~1s in both cases (as expected). 

Let me know if you think this test is appropriate?
